unnormalised: ## My Divorce Journey: Navigating Indian Family Law
normalised: My Divorce Journey: Navigating Indian Family Law

unnormalised: It feels surreal to be writing this, but here I am, sharing my experience with divorce in India. It's a path I never imagined I'd be on, but life, as they say, has other plans. My name is Priya Sharma, and this is my story of navigating the complexities of Indian family law.
normalised: It feels surreal to be writing this, but here I am, sharing my experience with divorce in India. It's a path I never imagined I'd be on, but life, as they say, has other plans. My name is Priya Sharma, and this is my story of navigating the complexities of Indian family law.

unnormalised: My marriage to Rakesh Kumar started like any other. We had a grand wedding on 12/12/2015, attended by almost 500 guests! Those early years were filled with love and laughter. We bought a flat in Mumbai, a 2BHK in Andheri, for Rs. 1.5 crore with a loan from HDFC Bank. We thought we were set.
normalised: My marriage to Rakesh Kumar started like any other. We had a grand wedding on twelfth December two thousand and fifteen, attended by almost five hundred guests! Those early years were filled with love and laughter. We bought a flat in Mumbai, a two B H K in Andheri, for rupee one point five crore with a loan from H D F C Bank. We thought we were set.

unnormalised: Slowly, things started to change. Rakesh's business, a small textile unit, faced setbacks. Stress mounted, and the pressures began to erode our relationship. We tried counseling. Dr. Mehra, a well-known therapist in Bandra, suggested we work on our communication. But the cracks were too deep.
normalised: Slowly, things started to change. Rakesh's business, a small textile unit, faced setbacks. Stress mounted, and the pressures began to erode our relationship. We tried counseling. Doctor Mehra, a well-known therapist in Bandra, suggested we work on our communication. But the cracks were too deep.

unnormalised: The final straw came when Rakesh, under immense financial pressure, took a loan of Rs. 20 lakh without my knowledge, using our joint property as collateral. I discovered this through a notice from ICICI Bank on 20/07/2022. I felt betrayed and lost.
normalised: The final straw came when Rakesh, under immense financial pressure, took a loan of rupee twenty lakh without my knowledge, using our joint property as collateral. I discovered this through a notice from I C I C I Bank on twentieth July two thousand and twenty two. I felt betrayed and lost.

unnormalised: I knew then that divorce was the only option. I consulted Adv. Gupta, a family law specialist recommended by a friend. He explained the grounds for divorce under the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955. Cruelty and financial deceit seemed most relevant to my case. He quoted a fee of Rs 50,000 for handling the case.
normalised: I knew then that divorce was the only option. I consulted Advocate Gupta, a family law specialist recommended by a friend. He explained the grounds for divorce under the Hindu Marriage Act, one thousand nine hundred and fifty five. Cruelty and financial deceit seemed most relevant to my case. He quoted a fee of rupee fifty thousand for handling the case.

unnormalised: The initial court date was set for 15/09/2022 at 10:30 AM in the Mumbai Family Court. The process was daunting. Filing the petition, gathering evidence, and attending hearings felt like a full-time job. It was emotionally draining, especially dealing with the stigma still attached to divorce in our society.
normalised: The initial court date was set for fifteenth September two thousand and twenty two at ten thirty A M in the Mumbai Family Court. The process was daunting. Filing the petition, gathering evidence, and attending hearings felt like a full-time job. It was emotionally draining, especially dealing with the stigma still attached to divorce in our society.

unnormalised: One of the biggest hurdles was the issue of alimony. Adv. Gupta advised me that I was entitled to a fair settlement, considering Rakesh's income and assets. We negotiated for months, eventually agreeing on a settlement of Rs. 30 lakh, payable in installments.
normalised: One of the biggest hurdles was the issue of alimony. Advocate Gupta advised me that I was entitled to a fair settlement, considering Rakesh's income and assets. We negotiated for months, eventually agreeing on a settlement of rupee thirty lakh, payable in installments.

unnormalised: Child custody wasn't an issue since we didn't have any children. However, dividing our joint property was another challenge. The flat, now valued at approximately Rs. 2 crore, was a major point of contention. Ultimately, we agreed to sell it and split the proceeds equally.
normalised: Child custody wasn't an issue since we didn't have any children. However, dividing our joint property was another challenge. The flat, now valued at approximately rupee two crore, was a major point of contention. Ultimately, we agreed to sell it and split the proceeds equally.

unnormalised: The divorce decree finally came through on 05/01/2023. It was a bittersweet moment. Relief washed over me, but also a profound sense of sadness for what could have been. The entire process, from initial consultation to the final judgment, took almost 6 months.
normalised: The divorce decree finally came through on fifth January two thousand and twenty three. It was a bittersweet moment. Relief washed over me, but also a profound sense of sadness for what could have been. The entire process, from initial consultation to the final judgment, took almost six months.

unnormalised: Looking back, I realize how crucial it is to seek legal advice early on. Understanding your rights and responsibilities under the law is essential. Divorce is never easy, but navigating it with clarity and support can make a world of difference. And to anyone going through something similar, remember, you are not alone. There is life after divorce, a chance to rebuild and find happiness again.
